node.name: continuity-check
node.description: Continuity Check RPC operation as per RFC 7276.None

node.name: destination-tp
node.description: Destination test point.None

node.name: tp-location-type
node.description: Test point address type.None

node.name: mac-address
node.description: MAC address based TP addressing.None

node.name: mac-address
node.description: MAC address.None

node.name: ipv4-address
node.description: IP address based TP addressing.None

node.name: ipv4-address
node.description: IPv4 address.None

node.name: ipv6-address
node.description: IPv6 address based TP addressing.None

node.name: ipv6-address
node.description: IPv6 address.None

node.name: tp-attribute
node.description: Test Point Attribute Container.None

node.name: tp-attribute-type
node.description: Test point type.None

node.name: tp-attribute-value
node.description: Test point value.None

node.name: ip-prefix
node.description: Generic IPv4/IPv6 prefix. See Sections 3.2.13 and 3.2.14 of RFC 8029.None

node.name: bgp
node.description: BGP Labeled IPv4/IPv6 Prefix. See Sections 3.2.11 and 3.2.12 of RFC 8029 for details.None

node.name: tunnel-interface
node.description: Basic IPv4/IPv6 Tunnel ID. See Sections 3.2.3 and 3.2.4 of RFC 8029 for details.None

node.name: remote-pe-address
node.description: Remote PE address. See Section 3.2.8 of RFC 8029 for details.None

node.name: pw-id
node.description: Pseudowire ID is a non-zero 32-bit ID. See Sections 3.2.8 and 3.2.9 of RFC 8029 for details.None

node.name: route-distinguisher
node.description: Route Distinguisher is an 8-octet identifier used to distinguish information about various L2VPNs advertised by a node.None

node.name: sender-ve-id
node.description: Sender's VE ID. The VE ID (VPLS Edge Identifier) is a 2-octet identifier.None

node.name: receiver-ve-id
node.description: Receiver's VE ID. The VE ID (VPLS Edge Identifier) is a 2-octet identifier.None

node.name: root-address
node.description: Root address choice.None

node.name: source-address
node.description: IP address.None

node.name: group-ip-address
node.description: Group IP address.None

node.name: as-number
node.description: The AS number that identifies an Autonomous System.None

node.name: lsp-id
node.description: LSP ID is an identifier of a LSP within a MPLS network.None

node.name: system-info
node.description: Router ID container.None

node.name: router-id
node.description: Router ID assigned to this node.None

node.name: source-interface
node.description: Source interface.None

node.name: outbound-interface
node.description: Outbound interface.None

node.name: vrf
node.description: Virtual Routing and Forwarding (VRF) instance.None

node.name: session-type
node.description: Indicate which kind of activation will be used by the current session.None

node.name: count
node.description: Specifies the number of packets that will be sent. By default, the packet number is set to 5.None

node.name: ttl
node.description: Time to live (TTL) used to limit the lifetime of data packets transmitted in the network to prevent looping. The TTL value is decremented for every hop that the packet traverses. If the TTL is zero, the data packet will be discarded.None

node.name: packet-size
node.description: Packet size of the Continuity Check message, in octets. By default, the packet size is set to 64 octets.None

node.name: response-info
node.description: Status code and status-sub-code for Continuity Check RPC operation.None

node.name: protocol-id
node.description: Protocol used in the Continuity Check message. This could be a standard protocol (e.g., TCP/IP protocols, MPLS, etc.) or a proprietary protocol as identified by this field.None

node.name: protocol-id-meta-data
node.description: An optional metadata related to the protocol ID. For example, this could be the Internet Protocol number for standard Internet Protocols used for help with protocol processing.None

node.name: status-code
node.description: Status code for Continuity Check RPC operation. This could be a basic status code (e.g., destination is reachable or destination is not reachable; see RFC 7276) or some customized status code as identified by this field.None

node.name: status-sub-code
node.description: An optional status-sub-code for Continuity Check RPC operation. If the basic status code is destination reachable, this status-sub-code doesn't need to be specified. If the basic status code is destination unreachable, the status-sub-code can be used to specify the detailed reasons. This could be a basic sub-status-code (such as an invalid Continuity Check) or other error codes specific to the protocol under use for the Continuity Checks. For example, if ICMP is the protocol under use, the error codes defined in RFC 4443 can be used to specify the reasons specific to ICMP. This technology-specific status-sub-code can be defined in technology-specific models.None

node.name: src-test-point
node.description: Source test point.None

node.name: ni
node.description: The ni is used to describe virtual resource partitioning that may be present on a network device. An example of a common industry term for virtual resource partitioning is 'VRF instance'.None

node.description: Generic IPv4/IPv6 prefix. See Sections 3.2.13 and 3.2.14 of RFC 8029.None

node.name: bgp
node.description: BGP Labeled IPv4/IPv6 Prefix. See Sections 3.2.11 and 3.2.12 of RFC 8029 for details.None

node.description: Basic IPv4/IPv6 Tunnel ID. See Sections 3.2.3 and 3.2.4 of RFC 8029 for details.None

node.description: Pseudowire ID is a non-zero 32-bit ID. See Sections 3.2.8 and 3.2.9 of RFC 8029 for details.None

node.name: route-distinguisher
node.description: Route Distinguisher is an 8-octet identifier used to distinguish information about various L2VPNs advertised by a node.None

node.name: sender-ve-id
node.description: Sender's VE ID. The VE ID (VPLS Edge Identifier) is a 2-octet identifier.None

node.name: receiver-ve-id
node.description: Receiver's VE ID. The VE ID (VPLS Edge Identifier) is a 2-octet identifier.None

node.name: root-address
node.description: Root address choice.None

node.name: source-address
node.description: IP address.None

node.name: group-ip-address
node.description: Group IP address.None

node.name: as-number
node.description: The AS number that identifies an Autonomous System.None

node.name: lsp-id
node.description: LSP ID is an identifier of a LSP within a MPLS network.None

node.name: system-info
node.description: Router ID container.None

node.name: router-id
node.description: Router ID assigned to this node.None

node.name: ingress-intf-name
node.description: Ingress interface name.None

node.name: sequence-number
node.description: Sequence number in data packets. A value of zero indicates that no sequence number is sent.None

node.name: hop-cnt
node.description: Hop count. A value of zero indicates that no hop count is sent.None

node.name: session-packet-statistics
node.description: Statistics per session packet.None

node.name: rx-packet-count
node.description: Total count of received OAM packets. The value of count will be set to zero (0) on creation and will thereafter increase monotonically until it reaches a maximum value of 2^32-1 (4294967295 decimal), when it wraps around and starts increasing again from zero.None

node.name: tx-packet-count
node.description: Total count of transmitted OAM packets. The value of count will be set to zero (0) on creation and will thereafter increase monotonically until it reaches a maximum value of 2^32-1 (4294967295 decimal), when it wraps around and starts increasing again from zero.None

node.name: rx-bad-packet
node.description: Total number of received bad OAM packets. The value of count will be set to zero (0) on creation and will thereafter increase monotonically until it reaches a maximum value of 2^32-1 (4294967295 decimal), when it wraps around and starts increasing again from zero.None

node.name: tx-packet-failed
node.description: Total number of OAM packets that failed when sent. The value of count will be set to zero (0) on creation and will thereafter increase monotonically until it reaches a maximum value of 2^32-1 (4294967295 decimal), when it wraps around and starts increasing again from zero.None

node.name: session-error-statistics
node.description: Per-session error statistics.None

node.name: packet-loss-count
node.description: Total count of received packet drops. The value of count will be set to zero (0) on creation and will thereafter increase monotonically until it reaches a maximum value of 2^32-1 (4294967295 decimal), when it wraps around and starts increasing again from zero.None

node.name: loss-ratio
node.description: Loss ratio of the packets. Expressed as percentage of packets lost with respect to packets sent.None

node.name: packet-reorder-count
node.description: Total count of received packets that were reordered. The value of count will be set to zero (0) on creation and will thereafter increase monotonically until it reaches a maximum value of 2^32-1 (4294967295 decimal), when it wraps around and starts increasing again from zero.None

node.name: packets-out-of-seq-count
node.description: Total count of packets received out of sequence. The value of count will be set to zero (0) on creation and will thereafter increase monotonically until it reaches a maximum value of 2^32-1 (4294967295 decimal), when it wraps around and starts increasing again from zero.None

node.name: packets-dup-count
node.description: Total count of received packet duplicates. The value of count will be set to zero (0) on creation and will thereafter increase monotonically until it reaches a maximum value of 2^32-1 (4294967295 decimal), when it wraps around and starts increasing again from zero.None

node.name: session-delay-statistics
node.description: Session delay summarized information. By default, a one-way measurement protocol (e.g., OWAMP) is used to measure delay. When a two-way measurement protocol (e.g., TWAMP) is used instead, it can be indicated using the protocol-id defined in RPC operation of retrieval methods for connectionless OAM (RFC 8533), i.e., set protocol-id as OWAMP. Note that only one measurement protocol for delay is specified for interoperability reasons.None

node.name: time-unit-value
node.description: Time units, where the options are s, ms, ns, etc.None

node.name: min-delay-value
node.description: Minimum delay value observed.None

node.name: max-delay-value
node.description: Maximum delay value observed.None

node.name: average-delay-value
node.description: Average delay value observed.None

node.name: session-jitter-statistics
node.description: Summarized information about session jitter. By default, jitter is measured using IP Packet Delay Variation (IPDV) as defined in RFC 3393. When the other measurement method is used instead (e.g., Packet Delay Variation used in ITU-T Recommendation Y.1540, it can be indicated using protocol-id-meta-data defined in RPC operation of retrieval methods for connectionless OAM (RFC 8533). Note that only one measurement method for jitter is specified for interoperability reasons.None

node.name: unit-value
node.description: Time units, where the options are s, ms, ns, etc.None

node.name: min-jitter-value
node.description: Minimum jitter value observed.None

node.name: max-jitter-value
node.description: Maximum jitter value observed.None

node.name: average-jitter-value
node.description: Average jitter value observed.None

node.name: path-discovery
node.description: Path discovery RPC operation as per RFC 7276.None

node.description: Destination test point.None

node.description: Generic IPv4/IPv6 prefix. See Sections 3.2.13 and 3.2.14 of RFC 8029.None

node.name: bgp
node.description: BGP Labeled IPv4/IPv6 Prefix. See Sections 3.2.11 and 3.2.12 of RFC 8029 for details.None

node.description: Route Distinguisher is an 8-octet identifier used to distinguish information about various L2VPNs advertised by a node.None

node.name: sender-ve-id
node.description: Sender's VE ID. The VE ID (VPLS Edge Identifier) is a 2-octet identifier.None

node.name: receiver-ve-id
node.description: Receiver's VE ID. The VE ID (VPLS Edge Identifier) is a 2-octet identifier.None

node.name: root-address
node.description: Root address choice.None

node.name: source-address
node.description: IP address.None

node.name: group-ip-address
node.description: Group IP address.None

node.name: as-number
node.description: The AS number that identifies an Autonomous System.None

node.name: lsp-id
node.description: LSP ID is an identifier of a LSP within a MPLS network.None

node.name: system-info
node.description: Router ID container.None

node.name: router-id
node.description: Router ID assigned to this node.None

node.name: source-interface
node.description: Source interface.None

node.name: outbound-interface
node.description: Outbound interface.None

node.name: vrf
node.description: Virtual Routing and Forwarding (VRF) instance.None

node.name: session-type
node.description: Indicate which kind of activation will be used by the current session.None

node.name: max-ttl
node.description: Maximum TTL indicates the maximum number of hops that a packet is permitted to travel before being discarded by a router. By default, the maximum TTL is set to 255.None

node.name: response-list
node.description: Path discovery response list.None

node.name: response-index
node.description: Response index.None

node.name: protocol-id
node.description: Protocol used in path discovery. This could be a standard protocol (e.g., TCP/IP protocols, MPLS, etc.) or a proprietary protocol as identified by this field.None

node.name: protocol-id-meta-data
node.description: An optional metadata related to the protocol ID. For example, this could be the Internet Protocol number for standard Internet Protocols used for help with protocol processing.None

node.name: status-code
node.description: Status code for Continuity Check RPC operation. This could be a basic status code (e.g., destination is reachable or destination is not reachable) or some customized status code as identified by this field.None

node.name: status-sub-code
node.description: An optional status-sub-code for Continuity Check RPC operation. If the basic status code is destination reachable, this status-sub-code doesn't need to be specified. If the basic status code is destination unreachable, the status-sub-code can be used to specify the detailed reasons. This could be a basic sub-status-code (such as an invalid Continuity Check) or other error codes specific to the protocol under use for Continuity Checks. For example, if ICMP is the protocol under use, the error codes defined in RFC 4443 can be used to specify the reasons specific to ICMP. This technology-specific status-sub-code can be defined in technology-specific models.None

node.description: Total number of received bad OAM packets. The value of count will be set to zero (0) on creation and will thereafter increase monotonically until it reaches a maximum value of 2^32-1 (4294967295 decimal), when it wraps around and starts increasing again from zero.None

node.description: Total number of OAM packets that failed when sent. The value of count will be set to zero (0) on creation and will thereafter increase monotonically until it reaches a maximum value of 2^32-1 (4294967295 decimal), when it wraps around and starts increasing again from zero.None

node.description: Per-session error statistics.None

node.name: packet-loss-count
node.description: Total count of received packet drops. The value of count will be set to zero (0) on creation and will thereafter increase monotonically until it reaches a maximum value of 2^32-1 (4294967295 decimal), when it wraps around and starts increasing again from zero.None

node.description: Loss ratio of the packets. Expressed as percentage of packets lost with respect to packets sent.None

node.name: packet-reorder-count
node.description: Total count of received packets that were reordered. The value of count will be set to zero (0) on creation and will thereafter increase monotonically until it reaches a maximum value of 2^32-1 (4294967295 decimal), when it wraps around and starts increasing again from zero.None

node.description: Total count of packets received out of sequence. The value of count will be set to zero (0) on creation and will thereafter increase monotonically until it reaches a maximum value of 2^32-1 (4294967295 decimal), when it wraps around and starts increasing again from zero.None

node.description: Total count of received packet duplicates. The value of count will be set to zero (0) on creation and will thereafter increase monotonically until it reaches a maximum value of 2^32-1 (4294967295 decimal), when it wraps around and starts increasing again from zero.None

node.name: session-delay-statistics
node.description: Session delay summarized information. By default, a one-way measurement protocol (e.g., OWAMP) is used to measure delay. When a two-way measurement protocol (e.g., TWAMP) is used instead, it can be indicated using the protocol-id defined in RPC operation of retrieval methods for connectionless OAM (RFC 8533), i.e., set protocol-id as OWAMP. Note that only one measurement protocol for delay is specified for interoperability reasons.None

node.name: time-unit-value
node.description: Time units, where the options are s, ms, ns, etc.None

node.name: min-delay-value
node.description: Minimum delay value observed.None

node.name: max-delay-value
node.description: Maximum delay value observed.None

node.name: average-delay-value
node.description: Average delay value observed.None

node.name: session-jitter-statistics
node.description: Summarized information about session jitter. By default, jitter is measured using IP Packet Delay Variation (IPDV) as defined in RFC 3393. When the other measurement method is used instead (e.g., Packet Delay Variation used in ITU-T Recommendation Y.1540, it can be indicated using protocol-id-meta-data defined in RPC operation of retrieval methods for connectionless OAM (RFC 8533). Note that only one measurement method for jitter is specified for interoperability reasons.None

node.name: unit-value
node.description: Time units, where the options are s, ms, ns, etc.None

node.name: min-jitter-value
node.description: Minimum jitter value observed.None

node.name: max-jitter-value
node.description: Maximum jitter value observed.None

node.name: average-jitter-value
node.description: Average jitter value observed.None

node.name: path-verification
node.description: Optional information related to path verification.None

node.name: flow-info
node.description: Information that refers to the flow.None

node.name: session-path-verification-statistics
node.description: OAM path verification statistics per session.None

node.name: verified-count
node.description: Total number of OAM packets that went through a path as intended. The value of count will be set to zero (0) on creation and will thereafter increase monotonically until it reaches a maximum value of 2^32-1 (4294967295 decimal), when it wraps around and starts increasing again from zero.None

node.name: failed-count
node.description: Total number of OAM packets that went through an unintended path. The value of count will be set to zero (0) on creation and will thereafter increase monotonically until it reaches a maximum value of 2^32-1 (4294967295 decimal), when it wraps around and starts increasing again from zero.None

node.name: path-trace-info
node.description: Optional per-hop path trace information about test points. The path trace information list typically has a single element for per-hop cases such as path-discovery RPC operation but allows a list of hop-related information for other types of data retrieval methods.None

node.name: path-trace-info-list
node.description: Path trace information list.None

node.name: index
node.description: Trace information index.None

node.name: ni
node.description: The ni is used to describe virtual resource partitioning that may be present on a network device. An example of a common industry term for virtual resource partitioning is 'VRF instance'.None

node.name: tp-location-type
node.description: Test point address type.None

node.name: mac-address
node.description: MAC address based TP addressing.None

node.name: mac-address
node.description: MAC address.None

node.name: ipv4-address
node.description: IP address based TP addressing.None

node.name: ipv4-address
node.description: IPv4 address.None

node.name: ipv6-address
node.description: IPv6 address based TP addressing.None

node.name: ipv6-address
node.description: IPv6 address.None

node.name: tp-attribute
node.description: Test Point Attribute Container.None

node.name: tp-attribute-type
node.description: Test point type.None

node.name: tp-attribute-value
node.description: Test point value.None

node.name: ip-prefix
node.description: Generic IPv4/IPv6 prefix. See Sections 3.2.13 and 3.2.14 of RFC 8029.None

node.name: bgp
node.description: BGP Labeled IPv4/IPv6 Prefix. See Sections 3.2.11 and 3.2.12 of RFC 8029 for details.None

node.name: tunnel-interface
node.description: Basic IPv4/IPv6 Tunnel ID. See Sections 3.2.3 and 3.2.4 of RFC 8029 for details.None

node.name: remote-pe-address
node.description: Remote PE address. See Section 3.2.8 of RFC 8029 for details.None

node.name: pw-id
node.description: Pseudowire ID is a non-zero 32-bit ID. See Sections 3.2.8 and 3.2.9 of RFC 8029 for details.None

node.name: route-distinguisher
node.description: Route Distinguisher is an 8-octet identifier used to distinguish information about various L2VPNs advertised by a node.None

node.name: sender-ve-id
node.description: Sender's VE ID. The VE ID (VPLS Edge Identifier) is a 2-octet identifier.None

node.name: receiver-ve-id
node.description: Receiver's VE ID. The VE ID (VPLS Edge Identifier) is a 2-octet identifier.None

node.name: root-address
node.description: Root address choice.None

node.name: source-address
node.description: IP address.None

node.name: group-ip-address
node.description: Group IP address.None

node.name: as-number
node.description: The AS number that identifies an Autonomous System.None

node.name: lsp-id
node.description: LSP ID is an identifier of a LSP within a MPLS network.None

node.name: system-info
node.description: Router ID container.None

node.name: router-id
node.description: Router ID assigned to this node.None

node.name: timestamp-type
node.description: Type of timestamp, such as Truncated PTP or NTP.None

node.name: timestamp-64bit
node.description: Container for 64-bit timestamp. The Network Time Protocol (NTP) 64-bit timestamp format is defined in RFC 5905. The PTP truncated timestamp format is defined in IEEE 1588v1.None

node.name: timestamp-sec
node.description: Absolute timestamp in seconds as per IEEE 1588v2 or seconds part in 64-bit NTP timestamp.None

node.name: timestamp-nanosec
node.description: Fractional part in nanoseconds as per IEEE 1588v2 or fractional part in 64-bit NTP timestamp.None

node.name: timestamp-80bit
node.description: Container for 80-bit timestamp.None

node.name: timestamp-sec
node.description: 48-bit timestamp in seconds as per IEEE 1588v2.None

node.name: timestamp-nanosec
node.description: Fractional part in nanoseconds as per IEEE 1588v2.None

node.name: ntp-timestamp-32bit
node.description: Container for 32-bit timestamp RFC5905.None

node.name: timestamp-sec
node.description: Timestamp in seconds as per short-format NTP.None

node.name: timestamp-nanosec
node.description: Truncated fractional part in 16-bit NTP timestamp.None

node.name: icmp-timestamp-32bit
node.description: Container for 32-bit timestamp. See RFC 792 for ICMP timestamp format.None

node.name: timestamp-millisec
node.description: Timestamp in milliseconds for ICMP timestamp.None

node.name: ingress-intf-name
node.description: Ingress interface name.None

node.name: egress-intf-name
node.description: Egress interface name.None

node.name: queue-depth
node.description: Length of the queue of the interface from where the packet is forwarded out. The queue depth could be the current number of memory buffers used by the queue, and a packet can consume one or more memory buffers, thus constituting device-level information.None

node.name: transit-delay
node.description: Time in nanoseconds that the packet spent transiting a node.None

node.name: app-meta-data
node.description: Application-specific data added by node.None
